subclasses: MIST EXTRACTOR MESH
description: A <WIRE MESH DEMISTER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DEMISTER> that is using a wire mesh
A <MIST EXTRACTOR MESH> is a <WIRE MESH DEMISTER> located at the gas exit of a vessel in order to clear the gas flow of liquid droplets.
A physical object intended to catch fluid droplets

subclasses: MODEM, OSCILLATOR - DEMODULATOR
description: A <DEMODULATOR> is a <FunctionalObject> that is capable of <DEMODULATING>

subclasses: modem
description: A <MODEM> is a <MODULATOR> and a <DEMODULATOR> that converts one form of a signal to another that is suitable for transmission over communication circuits, typically from digital to analog and then from analog to digital

Short for modulator/demodulator. A communications device that converts one form of a signal to another that is suitable for transmission over communication circuits, typically from digital to analogue and then from analogue to digital

An <OSCILLATOR - DEMODULATOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and an <OSCILLATOR> and a <DEMODULATOR> that is a signal conditioning device that is extracting the original information-bearing signal from a carrier wave.

subclasses: DESCRIPTION
description: A <DESCRIPTOR> is a <FunctionalObject> with the purpose of <DESCRIBING>

subclasses: ISO 14048 DATA REPRESENTATIVENESS DEFINITION, APPLICATION DESCRIPTION, NORSOK EDS-004 DESCRIPTION DEFINITION, SERVICE DESCRIPTION, NORSOK I-001 REV3 DESCRIPTION DEFINITION, OPERATIONAL MODAL ANALYSIS DESCRIPTION, POSC CAESAR REGISTRATION STATUS, ISO 14041 DATA QUALITY DEFINITION, ABBREVIATION, ISPDM DESCRIPTION DEFINITION, NORSK HYDRO EDS DESCRIPTION
description: A <DESCRIPTION> is an <ExpressString> and a <DESCRIPTOR> that is <DESCRIBING> something
An <ISO 14048 DATA REPRESENTATIVENESS DEFINITION> is a <DESCRIPTION DEFINITION> that is a qualitative assessment of degree to which the data reflect the true population of interest
An <ISO 14041 DATA QUALITY DEFINITION> is a <DESCRIPTION DEFINITION> of the data that bears on their ability to satisfy stated requirements
An <ISPDM DESCRIPTION DEFINITION> is a <DESCRIPTION DEFINITION> that defines the rules for a description of data in the Industry Standard Pipeline Data Management
A <NORSOK I-001 REV3 DESCRIPTION> is a <DESCRIPTION DEFINITION> originating from NORSOK I-001 Revision 3
A <NORSOK EDS-004 DESCRIPTION DEFINITION> is a <DESCRIPTION DEFINITION> originating from NORSOK EDS-004
A <NORSK HYDRO EDS DESCRIPTION> is a <DESCRIPTION DEFINITION> originating from a Norsk Hydro EDS data sheet
A <POSC CAESAR REGISTRATION STATUS> is a <DESCRIPTION DEFINITION> that defines the rules for a description of the status in the POSC Caesar registration life cycle of an administered item
An <APPLICATION DESCRIPTION> is a <DESCRIPTION> of the purpose for which a physical object or activity is intended to be used
A <ABBREVIATION> is a <DESCRIPTION> that is a shortened form of another description, especially for another word
An <OPERATIONAL MODAL ANALYSIS DESCRIPTION> is a <DESCRIPTION> of an <OPERATIONAL MODAL ANALYSIS>
A <SERVICE DESCRIPTION> is a <DESCRIPTION> of the service of an item
A functional object which is a specification of the capabilities an object is intended to fulfill

subclasses: SUPPLY GRILLE DIFFUSER, EXTRACT GRILLE DIFFUSER, EXHAUST DIFFUSER, VALVE OUTLET DIFFUSER, INLET DIFFUSER, diffuser, AXIAL DIFFUSER
description: A <DIFFUSER> is a <FunctionalObject> that has the capability of <DIFFUSING> which is used in pumps to convert kinetic energy imparted by impeller to potential energy i.e. pressure head.
An <AXIAL DIFFUSER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DIFFUSER> intended for an axial flow machine where the pumped flow or compressed gas is guided axially either to the next stage or to the outlet
An <EXHAUST DIFFUSER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DIFFUSER> that is part of an exhaust system and that is intended to direct the flow

subclasses: EXTRACT GRILLE DIFFUSER WITH BALANCING DAMPER
description: An <EXTRACT GRILLE DIFFUSER> is an <HVAC GRILLE> and a <DIFFUSER> that extracts air vertically without any deflection

uniqueName: EXTRACT GRILLE DIFFUSER WITH BALANCING DAMPER
description: An <EXTRACT GRILLE DIFFUSER WITH BALANCING DAMPER> is an <EXTRACT GRILLE DIFFUSER> with a balancing damper

subclasses: SUPPLY GRILLE DIFFUSER WITH BALANCING DAMPER
description: An <SUPPLY GRILLE DIFFUSER> is an <HVAC GRILLE> and a <DIFFUSER> that supplies air vertically without any deflection

uniqueName: SUPPLY GRILLE DIFFUSER WITH BALANCING DAMPER
description: A <SUPPLY GRILLE DIFFUSER WITH BALANCING DAMPER> is a <SUPPLY GRILLE DIFFUSER> with a balancing damper

A physical object that contains a diverging channel-shaped chamber in which part of the kinetic energy of the fluid is converted into pressure energy

subclasses: FLUID REGULATOR CAP, MONORAIL, BYPASS, RAIL SHUNT, RAIL TRACK, SPRAY, VORTEX BREAKER, BAFFLE, CENTRALIZER, COMPASS, FLOW STRAIGHTENING VANE
description: A <DIRECTING OBJECT> is a <FunctionalObject> that is capable of <DIRECTING> in a given direction

subclasses: DISK BAFFLE, TRANSVERSE BAFFLE, AUXILIARY BAFFLE, INTERRUPTER BAR, OIL BAFFLE, IMPINGEMENT BAFFLE, PREFERENTIAL BAFFLE, DOUGHNUT BAFFLE, SEGMENTAL BAFFLE, LONGITUDINAL BAFFLE
description: A <BAFFLE> is  a <DIRECTING OBJECT> that is intended to direct a flow of fluid, without adding or extracting a significant amount of energy
A <DOUGHNUT BAFFLE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <BAFFLE> and the shape of an annular disc
A <DISK BAFFLE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <BAFFLE> and the shape of a disc
An <IMPINGEMENT BAFFLE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <BAFFLE> protecting internals in flow inlet area against full flow load exposure
An <AUXILIARY BAFFLE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <BAFFLE> that is auxiliary for a process
An <INTERRUPTER BAR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <BAFFLE> intended to reduce the velocity of liquid from a downcomer
A <PREFERENTIAL BAFFLE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <BAFFLE> that is the preferred baffle in a process

A <SEGMENTAL BAFFLE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <BAFFLE> that is mounted inside the shell in a shell and tube heat exchanger to force the shell-side flow across or alongside the tubes for a better performance

subclasses: DISK AND DOUGHNUT BAFFLE, DOUBLE SEGMENTAL BAFFLE
description: A <TRANSVERSE BAFFLE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <BAFFLE> and a <SUPPORT> that is mounted orthogonal to the tubes in a shell and tube heat exchanger to support the tubes and force the shell-side flow across the tubes for better performance
An <OIL BAFFLE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <BAFFLE> intended to guide oil through a vessel
A <LONGITUDINAL BAFFLE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <BAFFLE> that is oriented parallel to the tubes
A <BYPASS> is a <DIRECTING OBJECT> allowing a stream of fluids to be shunted past the device(s) through which it normally flows

subclasses: FIXED CENTRALIZER, CASING CENTRALIZER, BOW CENTRALIZER, ROTATING CENTRALIZER, ARM CENTRALIZER, FIXED THREADED CENTRALIZER, CONDUCTOR CENTRALIZER, PISTON SKIRT, ONE-PIECE CENTRALIZER
description: A <CENTRALIZER> i a <DIRECTING OBJECT> and the capability of guiding something into a centralised position
A <PISTON SKIRT> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <CENTRALIZER> that is a hollow cylinder or sleeve attched to the pistons lower part in trunk engines, and taking up the side-forces from the connecting rod

A <CASING CENTRALIZER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <CENTRALIZER> capable of guiding a casing into centralised position. Normally a cylindrical cage-like device fitted to a wells casing as it run to keep the casing centered in the borehole
A <CONDUCTOR CENTRALIZER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <CENTRALIZER> capable of centering a pipe into the conductor casing (the wells surface pipe)
A <FIXED THREADED CENTRALIZER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <FIXED CENTRALIZER> that is treaded to be kept into posistion
A <BOW CENTRALIZER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <CENTRALIZER> and a bow shape creating a spring effect
An <ARM CENTRALIZER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <CENTRALIZER> and an arm extending outward at an angle from the pipe to that it is fixed
An <ONE-PIECE CENTRALIZER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <CENTRALIZER> that is essentially manufactured in one piece, ie. cast
A <ROTATING CENTRALIZER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <CENTRALIZER> that can be made to rotatin relation to the pipe
A <FIXED CENTRALIZER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <CENTRALIZER> that is rigidly connected to the pipe

subclasses: compass, RADIO COMPASS, GYROCOMPASS, MAGNETIC COMPASS
description: A <COMPASS> is a <DIRECTING OBJECT> that indicates either a) magnetic bearings by alignment of its needle on the magnetic poles, or b) reference bearing by radio signal, or c) change of orientation in relation to a gyromaintained line

An instrument that indicates either a) magnetic bearings by alignment of its needle on the magnetic poles, or b) reference bearing by radio signal, or c) change of orientation in relation to a gyromaintained line

A <MAGNETIC COMPASS> is an <ARTEFACT> and a  <COMPASS> consisting of a magnetized needle turning freely on a pivot, used for determing magnetic bearings by alignment of its needle to the magnetic poles
A <RADIO COMPASS> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <COMPASS> that use signals from radio beacons for determining a bearing
A <GYROCOMPASS> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <COMPASS> consisting of a driven high speed wheel, specially mounted, so that its axis remains parallel to that of the earth
A <FLOW STRAIGHTENING VANE> is a <VANE> and a <DIRECTING OBJECT> that attenuates and minimizes flow eddies, rotation swirls and other undesirable flow patterns upstream of a flow meter

subclasses: RISER CAP
description: A <FLUID REGULATOR CAP> is a <DIRECTING OBJECT> intended to deflect, check, or regulate fluid flow and that can have any shape
A <RISER CAP> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <FLUID REGULATOR CAP> and a <CAP> that partly covers a riser in a bubble cap tray
A <MONORAIL> is  a <RAIL> and a <DIRECTING OBJECT> that is a single rail astride which or suspended from which railway vehicles, monorail trolleys or the like run
A <RAIL SHUNT> is a <DIRECTING OBJECT> that is capable of <SHUNTING> a <TRAIN>

subclasses: LOADING TRACK
description: A <RAIL TRACK> is a <RAIL> and a <DIRECTING OBJECT> that consists of two parallel steel rails, generally anchored perpendicular to beams or railroad ties of timber, concrete, or steel to maintain a consistent distance apart, to facilitate transport on the rails with vehicles arranged in a train without the need for steering
A <LOADING TRACK> is a <RAIL TRACK> that is intended for temporary placement of a vehicle or wagon for loading purpose
A <SPRAY> is a <DIRECTING OBJECT> whose purpose is being used for <SPRAYING>
A <VORTEX BREAKER> is a <DIRECTING OBJECT> intended to prevent the occurrence of a vortex in a fluid

description: An <INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> capable of <INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY MANAGEMENT>
a discipline addressing internal networks, security, and equipment to store, retrieve, transmit and manipulate data at a facility, etc. Specifically excluded facility control systems
An <INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY TEAM> is a <TEAM> in an <INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: Logistics Management Discipline, LOGISTICS TEAM
description: A <LOGISTICS MANAGEMENT DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> capable of <LOGISTICS MANAGEMENT>

a discipline addressing the management of the transport, storage, distribution, and warehousing of materials and finished goods. May also include transport and logistics of personnel, where applicable
A <LOGISTICS TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <LOGISTICS MANAGEMENT DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: MAINTENANCE ENGINEERING TEAM
description: A <MAINTENANCE ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <MAINTENANCE ENGINEERING>
A <MAINTENANCE ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <MAINTENANCE ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: MAINTENANCE MANAGEMENT TEAM, Maintenance Management Discipline
description: A <MAINTENANCE MANAGEMENT DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> capable of <MAINTENANCE MANAGEMENT>
a discipline addressing equipment reliability and planning required to maintain the equipment and other infrastructure. Includes procedures, spares, etc
A <MAINTENANCE MANAGEMENT TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <MAINTENANCE MANAGEMENT DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: MATERIALS AND CORROSION ENGINEERING TEAM, Materials Engineering Discipline
description: A <MATERIALS AND CORROSION ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <MATERIALS AND CORROSION ENGINEERING>

a discipline addressing material selection and methods to manage integrity for the facility lifecycle, including corrosion management through coatings, linings, cathodic protection, inhibition, weld procedures, etc
A <MATERIALS AND CORROSION ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <MATERIALS AND CORROSION ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: MECHANICAL ENGINEERING TEAM, Mechanical Engineering Discipline
description: A <MECHANICAL ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <MECHANICAL ENGINEERING>
a macro discipline used to classify content generally addressing a combination of Piping, HVAC, Rotating, or Static equipment, or any combination thereof
A <MECHANICAL ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <MECHANICAL ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

uniqueName: METOCEAN AND ICE DATA ACQUISITION DISCIPLINE
subclasses: METOCEAN AND ICE DATA ACQUISITION TEAM
description: A <METOCEAN AND ICE DATA ACQUISITION DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <METOCEAN AND ICE DATA ACQUISITION>

uniqueName: METOCEAN AND ICE DATA ACQUISITION TEAM
superclasses: METOCEAN AND ICE DATA ACQUISITION DISCIPLINE
description: A <METOCEAN AND ICE DATA ACQUISITION TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <METOCEAN AND ICE DATA ACQUISITION DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: Ocean Engineering Discipline, OCEAN ENGINEERING TEAM
description: A <OCEAN ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> capable of <OCEAN ENGINEERING>

a discipline addressing the collection and analysis of environmental conditions specific to offshore locations, including but not limited to metocean analysis, navigational analysis, ice studies, etc. Excludes structural design and loading
A <OCEAN ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in an <OCEAN ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: Operations Management Discipline, OPERATIONS MANAGEMENT TEAM
description: An <OPERATIONS MANAGEMENT DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> capable of performing <OPERATIONS MANAGEMENT>
a discipline related to the planning, scheduling and future operations management post turnover. Including but not limited to training materials, procedures, strategies, organization design, etc
An <OPERATIONS MANAGEMENT TEAM> is a <TEAM> in an <OPERATIONS MANAGEMENT DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: PETROLEUM PRODUCTION ENGINEERING TEAM
description: A <PETROLEUM PRODUCTION ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <PETROLEUM PRODUCTION ENGINEERING>
A <PETROLEUM PRODUCTION ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <PETROLEUM PRODUCTION ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: PETROPHYSICS TEAM
description: A <PETROPHYSICS DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> capable of <PETROPHYSICS>
A <PETROPHYSICS TEAM> is a <TEAM> in an <PETROPHYSICS DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: PIPELINE ENGINEERING TEAM, Pipeline Engineering Discipline
description: A <PIPELINE ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <PIPELINE ENGINEERING>

a discipline addressing the systems that are used to transport liquids and gases. Including but not limited to pipeline design hydraulics, routes &amp;amp; stability,specification and other accessories such as cathodic protection, pigging equipment etc
A <PIPELINE ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <PIPELINE ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: PIPING ENGINEERING TEAM, Piping Engineering Discipline
description: A <PIPING ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <PIPING ENGINEERING>
a mechanical engineering specialty addressing the design, routing, and control of flow inside process and utilities via piping and related specialty equipment
A <PIPING ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <PIPING ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: PROCESS ENGINEERING TEAM, Process Engineering Discipline
description: An <PROCESS ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> capable of <PROCESS ENGINEERING>
a discipline related to the design, operation, control, and optimization of chemical, physical, and biological processes. Including but not limited to process flow definition, process modeling, etc
An <PROCESS ENGINEERING TEAME> is a <TEAM> in an <PROCESS ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: Project Management and Engineering Discipline, PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND ENGINEERING TEAM
description: A <PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND ENGINEERING>

A macro discipline covering the administrative and management related items associated with a major capital project, including organization, cross-engineering discipline philosophies, basis of design, regulatory activities, etc
A <PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: Quality Management Discipline, QUALITY ASSURANCE TEAM
description: A <QUALITY ASSURANCE DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> capable of implementing <QUALITY ASSURANCE>
a discipline addressing quality planning, assurance, control and improvement
A <QUALITY ASSURANCE TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <QUALITY ASSURANCE DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: RESERVOIR ENGINEERING TEAM
description: A <RESERVOIR ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <RESERVOIR ENGINEERING>
A <RESERVOIR ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <RESERVOIR ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: Mechanical Rotating Engineering Discipline, ROTATING EQUIPMENT ENGINEERING TEAM
description: A <ROTATING EQUIPMENT ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <ROTATING EQUIPMENT ENGINEERING>

a mechanical engineering specialty addressing mechanical components used to add kinetic energy to any process in order to make a material move. The equipment may include pumps, turbines, gearboxes, compressors, engines, etc
A <ROTATING EQUIPMENT ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <ROTATING EQUIPMENT ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: Safety Discipline, SAFETY ENGINEERING TEAM
description: A <SAFETY ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <SAFETY ENGINEERING>
a discipline addressing assessment of condition, analysis of risk and mitigation of potential harm to personnel as a result of their working conditions or behaviors
A <SAFETY ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <SAFETY ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: Security Discipline, SECURITY SERVICE TEAM
description: A <SECURITY SERVICE DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <SECURITY SERVICE>
a discipline addressing assessment of condition, analysis of risk and mitigation of potential harm to physical assets from external forces
A <SECURITY SERVICE TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <SECURITY SERVICE DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: STATIC EQUIPMENT ENGINEERING TEAM, Mechanical Static Engineering Discipline
description: A <STATIC EQUIPMENT ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <STATIC EQUIPMENT ENGINEERING>

a mechanical engineering specialty addressing mechanical equipment with no rotating components. The equipment may include tanks, vessels, heat exchangers, and fired equipment such as furnaces and boilers
A <STATIC EQUIPMENT ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <STATIC EQUIPMENT ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING TEAM, Structural Engineering Discipline
description: A <STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING>
a civil engineering specialty addressing the design of structures which resist loads, specifically constructed of concrete and steel
A <STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> and a <STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: Subsea Engineering Discipline, SUBSEA ENGINEERING TEAM
description: A <SUBSEA ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <SUBSEA ENGINEERING>

A discipline addressing design and control of production systems to be installed on the sea floor as well as any support equipment which tether those systems to a facility. Including but not limited to flowlines, wellheads, umbilicals, risers, etc
A <SUBSEA ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <SUBSEA ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: TELECOMMUNICATIONS ENGINEERING TEAM, Telecommunications Discipline
description: A <TELECOMMUNICATIONS ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <TELECOMMUNICATIONS ENGINEERING>

a discipline addressing external communication systems. This typically includes, any systems or equipment used for transmission of information across a distance, such as coax cable, optical fiber, radio, dish, etc
A <TELECOMMUNICATIONS ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <TELECOMMUNICATIONS ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: WELL ENGINEERING TEAM
description: A <WELL ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE> is a <DISCIPLINE> that is capable of <WELL ENGINEERING>
A <WELL ENGINEERING TEAM> is a <TEAM> in a <WELL ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE>

subclasses: PISTON
description: A <DISPLACER> is a <FunctionalObject> that has the purpose of <DISPLACING> a <FLUID>

subclasses: BALANCE PISTON, NORSOK I-001 REV3 V01 BLOCK VALVE HYDRAULIC ACTUATOR PISTON, BALANCED VALVE PISTON, NORSOK I-001 REV3 V04 HYDRAULIC ACTUATOR PISTON, NORSOK I-001 REV3 V02 PNEUMATIC ACTUATOR PISTON, SLIDING VALVE, UNLOADER PISTON, NORSOK I-001 REV3 V02 HYDRAULIC ACTUATOR PISTON, PLUNGER
description: A <PISTON> is an <ENGINE COMPONENT> and a <DISPLACER> that is normally of the cylindrical shape and provided with a closed end, intended to reciprocate within a hollow outer cylinder to change the internal volume of the outer cylinder  in order to either discharge pressurized liquid or gas

uniqueName: NORSOK I-001 REV3 V01 BLOCK VALVE HYDRAULIC ACTUATOR PISTON
description: A <NORSOK I-001 REV3 V01 BLOCK VALVE HYDRAULIC ACTUATOR PISTON> is a <PISTON> that is a hydraulic valve actuator oiston conforming to the specification NORSOK I-001, Field Instrumentation, V01, Rev 3, April 2000

uniqueName: NORSOK I-001 REV3 V02 HYDRAULIC ACTUATOR PISTON
description: A <NORSOK I-001 REV3 V02 HYDRAULIC ACTUATOR PISTON> is a hydraulic actuator piston manufactured according to the specification NORSOK I-001, Field Instrumentation, V02, Rev 3, April 2000

uniqueName: NORSOK I-001 REV3 V02 PNEUMATIC ACTUATOR PISTON
description: A <NORSOK I-001 REV3 V02 PNEUMATIC ACTUATOR PISTON> is a <PISTON> that is a pneumatic actuator piston manufactured according to the specification NORSOK I-001, Field Instrumentation, V02, Rev 3, April 2000

uniqueName: NORSOK I-001 REV3 V04 HYDRAULIC ACTUATOR PISTON
description: A <NORSOK I-001 REV3 V04 HYDRAULIC ACTUATOR PISTON> is a <PISTON> that is a hydraulic actuator piston manufactured according to the specification NORSOK I-001, Field Instrumentation, V04, Rev 3, April 2000
A <PLUNGER> is a <PISTON> that is a single acting solid piston or a ram.

A <SLIDING VALVE> is a <PISTON> that is a rotating equipment component that is a specially formed piston which determines the effective volume ratios of the screws depending on the position of the sliding valve in order to control the flow rate.
A <UNLOADER PISTON> is a <PISTON> that positions the sliding valve push rod by means of pressurized liquid or gas.
A <BALANCE PISTON> is a <PISTON> used to balance axial thrust generated by the impellers
A <BALANCED VALVE PISTON> is a <PISTON> used in a <BALANCED RELIEF VALVE USING PISTON>. The balanced piston design is used for regulation of backpressure.

subclasses: DIGITAL DISPLAY, NAME PLATE, MARKER
description: A <DISPLAY> is a <FunctionalObject> that is capable of <DISPLAYING> something

subclasses: LED DISPLAY, LIQUID CRYSTAL DISPLAY, LCD ASSEMBLY
description: A <DIGITAL DISPLAY> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISPLAY> that gives the information in the form of characters (numbers or letters)
An <LCD ASSEMBLY> is  a <DIGITAL DISPLAY> and that is an assembly of a LCD display, protecting cover and a fixing device
An <LED DISPLAY> is a <DIGITAL DISPLAY> that is presenting the information by panel mounted light-emitting diodes
A <LIQUID CRYSTAL DISPLAY> is  a <DIGITAL DISPLAY> that is made up of any number of colour or monochrome pixels arrayed in front of a light source or reflector

subclasses: PIPELINE MARKER, CABLE TRAY MARKER, CABLE MARKER, TRENCH MARKER, CABLE CORE MARKER
description: A <MARKER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISPLAY> that is used to mark a position, place reached, etc
A <PIPELINE MARKER> is a <MARKER> that is used to mark a position on a pipeline
A <TRENCH MARKER> is a <MARKER> intended to mark the location of buried cables
A <CABLE TRAY MARKER> is  a <MARKER> that is intended to give identification to cable trays and ladders
A <CABLE MARKER> is a <MARKER> intended to identify cables
A <CABLE CORE MARKER> is a <MARKER> intended to be attached to cable cores for the purpose of identification

subclasses: NON-TUBULAR HEAT EXCHANGER NAME PLATE, OWNER NAME PLATE, CERTIFICATION BODY NAME PLATE, MANUFACTURER NAME PLATE
description: A <NAME PLATE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISPLAY> and that bears information about the item to which it is attached
A <NON-TUBULAR HEAT EXCHANGER NAME PLATE> is a <NAME PLATE> that is mounted on a non-tubular heat exchanger
A <CERTIFICATION BODY NAME PLATE> is a <NAME PLATE> that contains information about the certifier and the certification
A <MANUFACTURER NAME PLATE> is a <NAME PLATE> that contains information about the manufacturer of an item
An <OWNER NAME PLATE> is a <NAME PLATE> that contains information about the owner of an item

subclasses: DISTILLATION SEPARATOR, DISTILLATION UNIT, DISTILLATION COLUMN
description: A <DISTILLER> is a <FunctionalObject> that has a capability of <DISTILLING>

subclasses: STRIPPER, VACUUM COLUMN, PRESTRIPPER, SPLITTER, distillation column, STABILIZER COLUMN
description: A <DISTILLATION COLUMN> is  a <DISTILLATION SEPARATOR> and a <PROCESS COLUMN> and a <DISTILLER> intended to enable a distillation process
A process column intended to enable a distillation process
A <STABILIZER COLUMN> is  a <DISTILLATION COLUMN> in which <CRUDE OIL> is subjected to <STABILIZING(oil)>, resulting in <STABILIZED CRUDE>
A <STRIPPER> is  a <DISTILLATION COLUMN> and a <STRIPPER(function)> intended to remove light components from a fluid
A <PRESTRIPPER> is  a <DISTILLATION COLUMN> intended to distil fluid roughly before entering a stripper

subclasses: REFORMATE SPLITTER
description: A <SPLITTER> is a <DISTILLATION COLUMN> and a <SPLITTER(function)> intended to split a fluid into two fractions
A <VACUUM COLUMN> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTILLATION COLUMN> intended to withstand outside pressure

subclasses: DISTILLATION COLUMN
description: A <DISTILLATION SEPARATOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTILLER> and a <FLUID SEPARATOR> which separates the different molecules in a stream after their range of properties

A <DISTILLATION UNIT> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTILLER> and is intended to separate liquid into various fractions according to their boiling point or boiling range, by means of evaporation and recondensation

subclasses: DISTRIBUTOR PAN, SUBSEA DISTRIBUTION UNIT, VANE INLET DISTRIBUTOR, WEIR DISTRIBUTOR, GAS DISTRIBUTOR, CATALYST DISTRIBUTOR, SUBSEA MANIFOLD MODULE, POWER DISTRIBUTOR, STRESS DISTRIBUTOR, DISTRIBUTOR TRAY, LOGIC CAP, PREDISTRIBUTOR, LIQUID DISTRIBUTOR, ANNULAR DISTRIBUTOR, SPIDER, REDISTRIBUTOR
description: A <DISTRIBUTOR> is a <FunctionalObject> that is capable of <DISTRIBUTING>

A <ANNULAR DISTRIBUTOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> that is used to reduce momentum of the inlet fluid on a <HEAT EXCHANGER SHELL SIDE> instead of an impingement plate or impingement rods. They are common on <CONDENSER>s especially. The purpose is to avoid excessive tube <VIBRATION> caused by the <MASS FLOW> of the inlet <FLUID> concentrated on a small area of the <TUBE BUNDLE>

subclasses: CATALYST SPIDER
description: A <CATALYST DISTRIBUTOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> intended to distribute catalyst
A <CATALYST SPIDER> is a <CATALYST DISTRIBUTOR> that has a shape of a spider
A <DISTRIBUTOR PAN> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <PAN> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> used for the distribution of liquids

subclasses: LIQUID DISTRIBUTION TRAY, GRAVITY DISTRIBUTOR TRAY, REFLUX DISTRIBUTOR TRAY, LIQUID DISTRIBUTOR TRAY
description: A <DISTRIBUTOR TRAY> is a <TRAY> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> intended to distribute or redistribute a fluid
A <REFLUX DISTRIBUTOR TRAY> is a <DISTRIBUTOR TRAY> intended to distribute fluid that is re-entered into the column.
A <GRAVITY DISTRIBUTOR TRAY> is a <DISTRIBUTOR TRAY> that uses the force of gravity to distribute liquid.
A <LIQUID DISTRIBUTOR TRAY> is a <DISTRIBUTOR TRAY> intended to evenly distribute a liquid.
A <LIQUID DISTRIBUTION TRAY> is a <DISTRIBUTOR TRAY> intended to evenly distribute a liquid.

subclasses: gas distributor, BURP TUBE, AIR DISTRIBUTOR
description: A <GAS DISTRIBUTOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> intended to distribute or redistribute a vapour
A distributor intended to distribute or redistribute a vapour
An <AIR DISTRIBUTOR> is a <GAS DISTRIBUTOR> intended to disperse air in a fluid
A <BURP TUBE> is a <GAS DISTRIBUTOR> that is a porous pipe
A <LIQUID DISTRIBUTOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> intended to distribute a liquid

subclasses: logic cap
description: A <LOGIC CAP> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> for hydraulic and chemical <FLUID>s, which provide the ability to redirect services by replacing an outboard <MQC PLATE> with an <ROV>. Logic caps provide the flexibility to modify distribution of hydraulic or chemical services due to circuit failures or changes in system requirements. A logic cap consists of a stab plate mounted hydraulic couplers connected to HFL (Hydraulic Fluid Line) tubing and plumbed accordingly to suit the application
A retrievable and configurable device to route and re-route flow true the cap

subclasses: ELECTRICAL DISTRIBUTION UNIT
description: A <POWER DISTRIBUTOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a  <DISTRIBUTOR> of <POWER>
An <ELECTRICAL DISTRIBUTION UNIT> is a <POWER DISTRIBUTOR> with several power distribution points
A <PREDISTRIBUTOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> intended to fluidise fluid roughly before entering another distributor
A <REDISTRIBUTOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> intended to distribute substance as done before

subclasses: REFLUX SPIDER
description: A <SPIDER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> intended to evenly distribute a fluid and that has a typical spider shape
A <REFLUX SPIDER> is a <SPIDER> intended to distribute reflux fluid evenly

subclasses: FILLET
description: A <STRESS DISTRIBUTOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a  <DISTRIBUTOR> that is capable of <DISTRIBUTING> <STRESS> over a broad area and effectively make the parts more durable and capable of bearing larger loads
A <FILLET> is a <Feature> and a <STRESS DISTRIBUTOR> that is a rounding of an interior or exterior corner of a part design

subclasses: subsea distribution unit
description: A <SUBSEA DISTRIBUTION UNIT> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> where hydraulics, chemicals, electrical power and signals are distributed from the main umbilicals to different subsea systems
An artefact where hydraulics, chemicals, electrical power and signals are distributed from the main umbilicals to different subsea systems

subclasses: SUBSEA INJECTION MANIFOLD MODULE, SUBSEA PRODUCTION MANIFOLD MODULE
description: A <SUBSEA MANIFOLD MODULE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> located on the seabed that is a structural unit enclosing and supporting a subsea pipeline manifold
A <SUBSEA PRODUCTION MANIFOLD MODULE> is a <SUBSEA MANIFOLD MODULE> used to co-mingle production fluid from wells to a flowline
A <SUBSEA INJECTION MANIFOLD MODULE> is a <SUBSEA MANIFOLD MODULE> used to distribute injection fluid from an injection flowline to injection wells
A <VANE INLET DISTRIBUTOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> where an inlet fluid flow is distributed by means of plates that are more or less parallel

subclasses: WEIR TROUGH DISTRIBUTOR
description: A <WEIR DISTRIBUTOR> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DISTRIBUTOR> that has weirs as parts to guide the fluid
A <WEIR TROUGH DISTRIBUTOR> is a <WEIR DISTRIBUTOR> that includes troughs made from weirs to guide the fluid

subclasses: DIVERTER SPOOL, WELL FLUID DIVERTER, DIVERTER VALVE
description: A <DIVERTER> is a <FunctionalObject> that has a capability of <DIVERTING>

A <DIVERTER SPOOL> is a <RESISTOR> and a <DIVERTER>, connected in parallel with the series winding or the compole winding of a d.c. machine in order to divert some of the current from it, thereby varying the m.m.f. produced by the winding
A <DIVERTER VALVE> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <VALVE> and a <DIVERTER> that is a valve with multiple ports intended to divert flow in several directions and prevent intermixing

subclasses: diverter
description: A <WELL FLUID DIVERTER> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <DIVERTER> that provides a means of diverting an unexpected release of well <FLUID>s, primarily <GAS> and occasionally <SOLID>s, to a location at the extremeties of the rig where they can be discharged safely
A device that is providing diversion of something from an expected course or direction

subclasses: FIRE DIVIDER, BARRIER, PASS PARTITION PLATE, BULKHEAD PLATE, WALL, TUBE SHEET
description: A <DIVIDER(separator)> is a <FunctionalObject> that has a capability of <SEPARATING>
A <BULKHEAD PLATE> is a <DIVIDER(separator)> that divides a compartment into smaller volumes

subclasses: CLASS B FIRE DIVIDER, CLASS A FIRE DIVIDER, FIREWALL (stone), CLASS H FIRE DIVIDER
description: A <FIRE DIVIDER> is a <DIVIDER(separator)> that prevents the propagation of flames and smoke

A <CLASS H FIRE DIVIDER> is a <FIRE DIVIDER> that is sufficiently braced and shall prevent the propagation of flames and smoke for minimum of 2 hour of the standardized fire test for a hydrocarbon fire

A <CLASS B FIRE DIVIDER> is a <FIRE DIVIDER> that is sufficiently braced and shall prevent the propagation of flames and smoke for minimum of 30 minutes of the standardized fire test as described in ISO 834

A <CLASS A FIRE DIVIDER> is a <FIRE DIVIDER> that is sufficiently braced and shall prevent the propagation of flames and smoke for minimum of one hour of the standardized fire test as described in ISO 834
A <FIREWALL (stone)> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <WALL> and a <FIRE DIVIDER>
A <PASS PARTITION PLATE> is a <DIVIDER(separator)> that is intended to partition a shell and tube heat exchanger into different tube passes

subclasses: STATIONARY TUBE SHEET, DOUBLE TUBE SHEET, FLOATING TUBE SHEET, CLADDED TUBE SHEET
description: A <TUBE SHEET> is a <DIVIDER(separator)> and a <PLATE> and a <SUPPORT> that is intended to support tubes and to isolate the shell side from the tube side of a shell and tube heat exchanger
A <DOUBLE TUBE SHEET> is a <TUBE SHEET> that is an assembly of a pair of tube sheets with a gap between them, where one sheet seal the tube side fluid and the other seals the shell side fluid.
A <CLADDED TUBE SHEET> is a <TUBE SHEET> that is protected by one or more layers of other material.
A <STATIONARY TUBE SHEET> is a <TUBE SHEET> that is held in a fixed position with respect to the vessel shell.
A <FLOATING TUBE SHEET> is a <TUBE SHEET> that can move inside a shell in order to allow thermal expansion.

subclasses: BRICK WALL, BUND WALL, wall, CONCRETE WALL, FRAMEWORK WALL, OUTER WALL, FIREWALL (stone), MASONRY WALL
description: A <WALL> is a <DIVIDER(separator)> for space that may also insulate, protect, secure and support loads
which is flat and typically vertical suitable for separation

A <MASONRY WALL> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <WALL> that is commonly used for the walls of buildings, retaining walls and buildings. Brick and concrete block are the most common types of masonry in use in industrialized nations and may be either weight-bearing or a veneer
An <OUTER WALL> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <WALL> that is made to separate an outdoor environment from an indoor environment

A <BUND WALL> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <WALL>, constructed around a <STORAGE> where potentially polluting substances are handled, processed or stored, for the purposes of containing any unintended escape of material from that area until such time as remedial action can be taken
A <CONCRETE WALL> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <CONCRETE OBJECT> and a <WALL>
A <FRAMEWORK WALL> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <WALL> where the required loadbearing capabilities and rigidity is provided by a structural framework
A <BRICK WALL> is an <ARTEFACT> and a <WALL> erected using bricks

subclasses: SPECIFICATION, QUALITY PROCEDURE, HANDLING, SHIPPING AND STORAGE PROCEDURE, MATRIX REPRESENTATION, MAINTENANCE PROCEDURE, OPERATING PROCEDURE, PLANNING PROCEDURE, WELL KILLING PROCEDURE, STRATEGY DOCUMENT, SUMMARY, HISTOGRAM, LINE ITEM, MULTIMEDIA DOCUMENT, CORRESPONDENCE, INSTALLATION PROCEDURE, SCOPE OF WORK, DIAGRAM, EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURE, PHILOSOPHY REPORT, QUOTATION, general document, WARRANTY DOCUMENT, CERTIFICATE, INSPECTION PROCEDURE, TECHNICAL PROJECT DOCUMENTATION, NARRATIVE, COMMISSIONING PROCEDURE, CONTROL PROCEDURE, ASSURANCE PROCEDURE, PACKING AND SHIPPING PROCEDURE, DIRECTIVE, NOTICE, VENDOR DOCUMENT, ENQUIRY, COST CONTROL PROCEDURE, MANIFEST, REQUISITION, TERMS OF REFERENCE, PRESSURE TEST PROCEDURE, BROCHURE, PROPOSAL, WELDING PROCEDURE QUALIFICATION, CONTRACT, COUNTRY REGULATIONS PROCEDURE, SURFACE PROTECTION PROCEDURE, INTERFACE DOCUMENT, LIST, MAP, CORROSION INHIBITION SYSTEM DESIGN, TEST PROCEDURE, AGREEMENT RECORD, FORMING AND HEAT TREATMENT PROCEDURE, POLICY, VALIDATION PROCEDURE, WELDING REPAIR PROCEDURE, DATASHEET, REQUEST RECORD, JOB DESCRIPTION, NON-DESTRUCTIVE TEST PROCEDURE, CALCULATION SHEET, COMMUNICATIONS PROCEDURE, DOCUMENT AND DATA CONTROL PROCEDURE, INTERFACE PROCEDURE, CHANGE CONTROL PROCEDURE, WEIGHING PROCEDURE, DECLARATION, DRAWING, REPORT, CATALOG, CHART, PLAN, MATERIAL MANAGEMENT PROCEDURE, MEMORANDUM
description: A <DOCUMENT> is a <FunctionalObject> which has the purpose of <PROVIDING> a written, drawn, presented or recorded representation of thoughts

subclasses: REGULATORY AGREEMENT, general agreement
description: An <AGREEMENT RECORD> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> which records scope and obligations as mutually agreed between two or more parties
a document which records scope and obligations as mutually agreed between two or more parties

subclasses: PETROLEUM BUSINESS AREA AGREEMENT, PETROLEUM PRODUCTION LICENSE
description: A <REGULATORY AGREEMENT> is an <AGREEMENT RECORD> and a <REGULATION> recording a mutual agreement between owner/operators and regulatory agencies
An <ASSURANCE PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> for the assurance of quality, compliance, technical, value, cost and schedule

subclasses: EQUIPMENT BROCHURE
description: A <BROCHURE> is an <InformationObject> and a small <DOCUMENT> containing pictures and information about a product or service

An <EQUIPMENT BROCHURE> is  a <BROCHURE> that shows extracts from a vendor&#39;s published catalogue; Usually informal and held within a reference library, but may also be used to confirm equipment details during procurement

subclasses: STRESS CALCULATION, RELIABILITY, AVAILABILITY AND SAFETY INTEGRITY LEVEL CALCULATION, HYDRAULIC CALCULATION, CABLE SIZING CALCULATION, DESIGN CALCULATION, general calculation, WEIGHT CALCULATION, EQUIPMENT SIZING CALCULATION, LINE SIZING CALCULATION, SHORT CIRCUIT CALCULATION, HEAT EXCHANGER THERMAL RATING CALCULATION, PROCESS AND UTILITY CALCULATION, HEAT AND MASS BALANCE CALCULATION, RELIEF VALVE CALCULATION, FIRE EXTINGUISHANT CALCULATION
description: <CALCULATION SHEET> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> used for determining by mathematical process
a document showing inputs, formulas, rationale, and conclusions/mathematical results as required to enhance design or bound activities
A <LINE SIZING CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation of the <SIZE> of a <PIPING NETWORK SYSTEM>
A <DESIGN CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> prepared in order to prove that the item of equipment or system selected meets the design criteria
A <SHORT CIRCUIT CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> prepared to determine the capacity of electrical equipment under fault conditions.
A <CABLE SIZING CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation of the <SIZE> of an <ELECTRICAL CABLE>
A <EQUIPMENT SIZING CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation of the <SIZE> of an <EQUIPMENT ITEM>

A <FIRE EXTINGUISHANT CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation that is to prove that a given quantity of <FIRE EXTINGUISHING AGENT> will be delivered at a set rate and time

A <HEAT AND MASS BALANCE CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation involving process simulation and process calculations required for generation of heat and mass balance cases, including specific heating and cooling medium simulations

A <HEAT EXCHANGER THERMAL RATING CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation of the thermal effectiveness (heat transferred) and pressure drop of each stream in a <HEAT EXCHANGER>

A <HYDRAULIC CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation that is to indicate basis on which equipment is sized, including pipe friction losses, equipment elevations and terminal point static pressures. Includes Net Positive Suction Head calculations and other steady state conditions. Also includes calculation of hydraulic surge (synonym Water Hammer) for the purpose of determining valve sizing, closing speed, etc

A <PROCESS AND UTILITY CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation that is to prove that the item of equipment or system selected meets the design criteria. for the calculation input from the <HEAT AND MASS BALANCE SUMMARY> is being used

uniqueName: RELIABILITY, AVAILABILITY AND SAFETY INTEGRITY LEVEL CALCULATION
description: A <RELIABILITY, AVAILABILITY AND SAFETY INTEGRITY LEVEL CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation, such as an MTBF (Mean Time Between Failure) and SIL (Safety Integrity Level) calculation, to demonstrate starting and operating reliability/availability of purchased equipment
A <RELIEF VALVE CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation of the <SIZE> of a <RELIEF VALVE>; The result is documented in the <PROCESS SAFEGUARDING MEMORANDUM>
A <STRESS CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation of some form of <STRESS> in an <ARTEFACT>
A <WEIGHT CALCULATION> is a <CALCULATION SHEET> with a record of a calculation of the <WEIGHT> of the material inside engineering material <SHAPE>s

subclasses: SHAPE CATALOG, EQUIPMENT AND MATERIALS CATALOGUE
description: A <CATALOG> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> containing information as systematic arrangements of enumerated items giving descriptive details, a list or register in alphabetical or other methodical order
A <SHAPE CATALOG> is a <CATALOG> for geometric <SHAPES>s, with shape properties, that can be used in some graphical computer application
An <EQUIPMENT AND MATERIALS CATALOGUE> is a <CATALOGUE> that contains equipment and materials specifications, availability, prices, spare parts lists

subclasses: COMPLETION CERTIFICATE, general certificate, TEST CERTIFICATE, MATERIAL CERTIFICATE, EEX CERTIFICATE, APPROVAL CERTIFICATE, COUNTRY REGULATION COMPLIANCE CERTIFICATE, WELDER QUALIFICATION CERTIFICATE, WEIGHT CERTIFICATE, CALIBRATION CERTIFICATE, BASEEFA CERTIFICATE, HAZARDOUS AREA CERTIFICATE, STUDY REPORT
description: A <CERTIFICATE> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> that is offical and that affirms some fact
A <BASEEFA CERTIFICATE> is a <CERTIFICATE> issued by BASEEFA (British Approval Service for Electrical Equipment in Flammable Atmospheres)

a document certifying compliance with specified requirements. [e.g., certificates needed for re-certifying, occupancy certificate, product certificates].Not to be used if a more specific document type can be used. Can be used for singular/specialty deliverables which do not have a unique document type
An <EEX CERTIFICATE> is a <CERTIFICATE> documenting that a motor or other electrical component complie with the EEx requirements
A <WELDER QUALIFICATION CERTIFICATE> is a <CERTIFICATE> certifying a <WELDER> is qualified to perform work according to certain weld procedure
A <WEIGHT CERTIFICATE> is a <CERTIFICATE> certifying the correct gross weight for a piece of equipment including packing materials.  This typically should also document the center of gravity
A <STUDY REPORT> is a <CERTIFICATE> and a <REPORT> detailing the result of a professional evaluation and/or investigation of a specific subject
A <COMPLETION CERTIFICATE> is a <CERTIFICATE> certifying a <COMMISSIONING UNIT> has been successfully tested for functionality.
A <CALIBRATION CERTIFICATE> is a <CERTIFICATE> certifying that an <INSTRUMENTATION ITEM> has been calibrated to deliver an accurate output within a set operating range.

An <APPROVAL CERTIFICATE> is a <CERTIFICATE> that is issued by a recognised independent authority indicating the equipment has been manufactured in accordance with code/standard. For fire test certification the certificates are to be complete and as issued by the testing authority; A detailed definition of the <DATA> required in a particular context is given in the applicable instance of <DocumentDefinition>

A <COUNTRY REGULATION COMPLIANCE CERTIFICATE> is a <CERTIFICATE> that regulates minimum requirements for import and/or use of goods, as issued by countries or groups of countries, and accompanies shipments of equipment

A <HAZARDOUS AREA CERTIFICATE> is a <CERTIFICATE> that is issued by a recognised independent authority indicating that a type test has satisfied the specified standards; Examples of ratings include Intrinsically Safe and Explosion Proof
A <MATERIAL CERTIFICATE> is a <CERTIFICATE> documenting that the properties of a substance conform with specified requirements
A <TEST CERTIFICATE> is a <CERTIFICATE> documenting conformance with a specified test requirement

subclasses: change control procedure
description: A <CHANGE CONTROL PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> that describes how changes through Design, Construction and Commissioning shall be managed
a procedure describing how changes through Design, Construction and Commissioning will be managed

subclasses: CAUSE AND EFFECT DIAGRAM, ORGANIZATION CHART, general chart, GANNT CHART
description: A <CHART> is an <InformationObject> and a  <DOCUMENT> which has the purpose of <EXHIBITING> information in a methodical and/or tabulated form
a document which has the purpose of exhibiting information in a methodical and/or tabulated form

A <GANNT CHART> is a <CHART> that is an <InformationObject> and a type of bar chart that illustrates a project schedule. Gantt charts illustrate the start and finish dates of the terminal elements and summary elements of a project
A <CAUSE AND EFFECT DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> and a <CHART> that is showing the consequences of different errors
An <ORGANIZATION CHART> is a <CHART> containing data about organisational units and their relations
A <COMMISSIONING PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> with a step by step description of activities required to commission an object
A <COMMUNICATIONS PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> for cross-discipline, internal and external communications, with details on responsibilities and governance

subclasses: contract
description: A <CONTRACT> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> that describes a voluntary, deliberate, and legally binding agreement between two or more competent parties

a binding document which records a agreement and its related mutual obligations and commitments. Typically having effect on a project or the future life of a facility. For example a sales contract, maintenance contract, etc
A <CONTROL PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> intended to control a process

subclasses: correspondence
description: A <CORRESPONDENCE> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> that is any form of written communication sent or received in the course of affairs including transmittals, letters, postcards, memoranda, electronic mail, facsimiles, telegrams or cables
any form of written communication sent or received in the course of affairs including transmittals, letters, postcards, memoranda, electronic mail, facsimiles, telegrams or cables
A <CORROSION INHIBITION SYSTEM DESIGN> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> that is describing design requirements for corrosion inhibition based on a <CORROSION INHIBITION SELECTION REPORT>

subclasses: cost control procedure
description: A <COST CONTROL PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> for monitoring, controlling and reporting expenditures
a procedure for monitoring, controlling and reporting expenditures

A <COUNTRY REGULATIONS PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> for developing country regulation-specific documents or to submit this documents to regulatory authotities

subclasses: INDUCTION MOTOR DATA SHEET, HEAT AND MASS BALANCE SUMMARY, LOW VOLTAGE SWITCHBOARD DATA SHEET, VALVE DATA SHEET, POWER TRANSFORMER DATA SHEET, STREAM DATA SHEET, NOISE DATASHEET, general datasheet, AC GENERATOR DATA SHEET, CONVERTER DATA SHEET, INSTRUMENT DATA SHEET, PROCESS DATA SHEET, MANUFACTURER DATASHEET, LIGHTING PERFORMANCE DATASHEET, COMPONENT DATASHEET, WINCH DATA SHEET, INTEGRITY OPERATING ENVELOPE DATASHEET, HIGH VOLTAGE SWITCHBOARD DATA SHEET, THRUSTER DATA SHEET, WEIGHT DATA SHEET, PUMP DATA SHEET, UPS DATA SHEET, MATERIAL SAFETY DATASHEET
description: A <DATASHEET> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> with the purpose of <COMMUNICATING> <DATA>; it usually contains a set of defined fields within which <DATA> is supplied
a document with the purpose of communicating data; it usually contains a set of defined fields within which data is supplied
A <CONVERTER DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> for a <PROCESS SIGNAL CONVERTER>
A <POWER TRANSFORMER DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> for a <POWER TRANSFORMER>
A <WEIGHT DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> that records the distribution of weight in a structure and shows the center of gravity of that structure
A <LOW VOLTAGE SWITCHBOARD DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> for low voltage circuits
A <VALVE DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> for a <VALVE>
An <INDUCTION MOTOR DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET>s
A <THRUSTER DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> for a <THRUSTER>
An <AC GENERATOR DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> for an <ALTERNATING CURRENT GENERATOR>
An <UPS DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> (Uninterruptible Power Supply)
A <PUMP DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> for a <PUMP>
A <WINCH DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> for a winch
An <INSTRUMENT DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> for a <PROCESS INSTRUMENTATION ITEM>
A <HIGH VOLTAGE SWITCHBOARD DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> for high voltage circuits
A <STREAM DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> about the chemical composition, physical state, and quantities and qualities of flowing material

A <MANUFACTURER DATASHEET> is a <DATASHEET> and a <VENDOR DOCUMENT> which provides precise information about a equipment/model or package which shows how it meets the Equipment Specification and the Design Datasheet Requirements; includes noise and other test results prepared by manufacturer/supplier
A <HEAT AND MASS BALANCE SUMMARY> is a <DATASHEET> that contains all required process compositions and parameters for selected locations through the process

An <INTEGRITY OPERATING ENVELOPE DATASHEET> is a <DATASHEET> that specifies the lower and upper safe working operating parameters (temperature, pressure, composition, flow) that shall be used for sizing unit operations
A <LIGHTING PERFORMANCE DATASHEET> is a <DATASHEET> that contains one or more embedded <POLAR DIAGRAM>s with general performance data for specified <LUMINAIRE> types

A <MATERIAL SAFETY DATASHEET> is a <DATASHEET> that typically includes: - summary of physical and chemical properties of the substance - description of its harmful nature including potential impact on the health and safety of personnel and of the environment - precautions necessary to ensure its safe use and eventual disposal

A <NOISE DATASHEET> is a <DATASHEET> that defines required and/or actual sound power and sound pressure level limitations; A detailed definition of the <DATA> required in a particular context is given in the applicable instance of <DocumentDefinition>
A <PROCESS DATA SHEET> is a <DATASHEET> that gives process data for Detailed Engineering; this data is based on Heat and Material Balance information and includes safety margins where required
A <COMPONENT DATASHEET> is a <DATASHEET> about the components in a mixture, assembly or collection

subclasses: SAFETY DECLARATION
description: A <DECLARATION> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> with the purpose of giving a positive, explicit, or formal statement of the beginning of a state or condition containing basic information

A <SAFETY DECLARATION> is a <DECLARATION> that is  issued by an  asset owner to Regulatory Authority, demonstrating compliance with Regulatory Authority safety requirements. It documents the nature and scale of hazards of an industrial facility, lays out measures developed to ensure its industrial safety and readiness for emergency response in man-induced emergency situations

subclasses: SINGLE-LINE DIAGRAM, LOGIC DIAGRAM, PROCESS SAFEGUARDING FLOW SCHEME, SWITCHBOARD SCHEMATIC DIAGRAM, general diagram, HVAC FLOW DIAGRAM, NETWORK DIAGRAM, ELECTRICAL HOOK-UP DIAGRAM, CONSTRUCTION DIAGRAM, EARTHING DIAGRAM, HYDRAULIC AND PNEUMATIC DIAGRAM, CONNECTION DIAGRAM, BLOCK DIAGRAM, MATERIAL SELECTION DIAGRAM, CAUSE AND EFFECT DIAGRAM, PROCESS FLOW DIAGRAM, TERMINATION DIAGRAM, BLOCK FLOW DIAGRAM, ELECTRICAL SCHEMATIC DIAGRAM, FIRE FIGHTING FLOW SCHEME, WIRING DIAGRAM, THREE-LINE DIAGRAM, CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGRAM, ANCHORING DIAGRAM, INSTRUMENT HOOK UP DIAGRAM, HVAC DUCTING AND INSTRUMENT DIAGRAM, PIPING AND INSTRUMENTATION DIAGRAM, POLAR DIAGRAM, LIGHTING LAYOUT DIAGRAM, INSTRUMENT LOOP DIAGRAM, TIME-DISTANCE DIAGRAM, SYSTEM DIAGRAM, FLOOR PLAN, PROCESS CONTROLS DIAGRAM, schematic diagram
description: A <DIAGRAM> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> that represents functional information using a topology of symbols

a diagram not otherwise described in another document type. Not to be used if a more specific document type can be used. Can be used for singular/specialty deliverables which do not have a unique document type

a pictorial representation of the main elements and functions of a control circuit for electrical equipment with input/output sources (switches, relays etc.) and their relationships. Details logic functions of the circuit

A <LOGIC DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that presents component and system operational information using logic symbology; that results in a diagram that allows the user to determine the operation of a given component or system as the various input signals change

An <ELECTRICAL SCHEMATIC DIAGRAM> a <DIAGRAM> that gvies a graphical representation of an electrical circuit. Itshows the components and interconnections of the circuit using standardized symbolic representations. The presentation of the interconnections between circuit components in the schematic diagram does not necessarily correspond to the physical arrangements in the finished device. (Wikipedia)

A <WIRING DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that is a visual representation of the physical connections and physical layout of an electrical system or circuit. It shows how the electrical wires are interconnected and can also show where fixtures and components may be connected to the system
An <ELECTRICAL HOOK-UP DIAGRAM> is a <DDIAGRAM> that is showing electrical connections including the location of the connections, connections types, sizes etc

A <BLOCK FLOW DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> representing the activity model of a process, where the blocks represent Unit Operations (activities) and the connections between these blocks represent streams with stream data
A <CONSTRUCTION DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that is detailing assembly and fabrication

A <TERMINATION DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> for equipment, panels, junction boxes, etc. identifies all connections and cable terminations at input/output rails. Required for removal/hook up purposes and modifications. To include vendor interfaces
A <FLOOR PLAN> is a <DIAGRAM> that is detailing a building, rooms, doorways, cabinet and other permanent equipment installed. Including external layouts and elevation
An <ANCHORING DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> showing anchoring and mooring of offshore vessels and structures and the interaction of anchor lines with sub-sea pipelines and structures
An <EARTHING DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> detailing earthing (grounding) for plant and equipment and between modules and dissimilar structural elements

A <PROCESS SAFEGUARDING FLOW SCHEME> is a <DIAGRAM> that details all pen-ultimate and ultimate safeguarding elements for process and utility protection against uncontrolled loss of containment. It helps to demonstrate the safety of the plant
A <SWITCHBOARD SCHEMATIC DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that details main switchboards including protection relays and metering. More detailed than a One Line Diagram
A <THREE-LINE DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> describing an electrical system by depicting each line of that system. Example - positive, negative, and ground on a DC System.
A <TIME-DISTANCE DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> <REPRESENTING> <Activity>s in time and distance

A <POLAR DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> in which a point of origin is surrounded by a curve whose radius at any given point is proportional to the magnitude of some property measured in the direction of that point
A <CONNECTION DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that gives details of cable numbers and terminations between vendor packages, equipment and Contractor interfaces

A <CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> gives a pictorial representation of the main elements and functions of a control circuit/system with input/output sources (switches, relays etc.) and their relationships

A <FIRE FIGHTING FLOW SCHEME> is a <DIAGRAM> that details in schematic form the active fire fighting systems, equipment (fire pumps, deluge, monitor and Halon skids) piping, valves, tagged instruments and their relationships

An <INSTRUMENT HOOK UP DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that shows one or more of the following instrument impulse, pneumatic and electronic connections, pipe work, valves, fittings, flanges and support details with associated material take-off list
An <HVAC DUCTING AND INSTRUMENT DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that is a schematic representation of an HVAC system indicating all HVAC equipment items and their control interfaces

A <HVAC FLOW DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that is a schematic diagram depicting an HVAC ducting system, including all items of duct mounted equipment complete with tag numbers, flow rate and duct sizing information
A <HYDRAULIC AND PNEUMATIC DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that is a schematic diagram for hydraulic and/or pneumatic systems
A <LIGHTING LAYOUT DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that is a layout of lighting on a facility

A <MATERIAL SELECTION DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that is a schematic diagram showing materials selected for each component of the design. May include piping class breaks and vessel internals and includes corrosion loop diagrams that show boundary definitions
A <PIPING AND INSTRUMENTATION DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that shows equipment, piping networks, including the physical sequence of branches, reducers, and valves, instrumentation and controls

A <PROCESS FLOW DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that gives a functional representation of a process; it is in essence representing functional objects, without physical properties, that can handle the required Unit Operations and controls, and the data of the streams in between these objects
An <INSTRUMENT LOOP DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> showing measurement, control and actuator functions and their interconnection (cabling, junction boxes, etc.)
A <PROCESS CONTROLS DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that is a diagrammatic explanation of mechanisms/systems that monitor and control a process

A <BLOCK DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that shows the relation between the main functions or the main component in the system or instalation. This diagram shall identify the interface between the responsibilities of the customer and the supplier
A <SYSTEM DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that is a topological representation of a system in which the information content depends on a specific requirement
A <SINGLE-LINE DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> in which the polyphase links are represented by their equivalent single line
A <NETWORK DIAGRAM> is a <DIAGRAM> that is the graphical representation of a network topology

subclasses: INSTRUCTION, BUSINESS DIRECTIVE, GUIDELINE
description: A <DIRECTIVE> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> which guides a <Person> or an <Organization> its activities by means of imposing instructions, controls and requirements
A <GUIDELINE> is a <DIRECTIVE> and a <GUIDE>  that prescribes or advises on the execution of activities
A <BUSINESS DIRECTIVE> is a <DIRECTIVE> that is company specific and consists of instructions, controls and requirements imposed on an organisation to guide the performance of its business activities
An <INSTRUCTION> is a <DIRECTIVE> about something that must be done, often given by someone in authority

subclasses: document, data control procedure
description: A <DOCUMENT AND DATA CONTROL PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> for <CONTROLLING> the flow of project documents and data

superclasses: general procedure, DOCUMENT AND DATA CONTROL PROCEDURE
description: a procedure specifically for document and data control (IM). Includes Document Control charts and other procedure components

subclasses: ASSEMBLY DRAWING, FOUNDATION DESIGN DRAWING, FOUNDATION LOADING DRAWING, PIPE SUPPORT DETAIL, EMERGENCY EQUIPMENT AND EXITS DRAWING, TENDON DRAWING, INTERFACE DRAWING, general drawing, EQUIPMENT INSTALLATION DRAWING, SAFETY ZONE DRAWING, ROUTING DRAWING, UNDERGROUND SERVICE LAYOUT DRAWING, FOUNDATION DRAWING, INSULATION DRAWING, PIPING ISOMETRIC DRAWING, GENERAL ARRANGEMENT DRAWING, EQUIPMENT CROSS SECTION DRAWING, SUBSTRUCTURE STEEL DRAWING, CRANKSHAFT DRAWING, PNEUMATIC HOOK-UP DRAWING, EQUIPMENT LOCATION DRAWING, LOGIC AND SEQUENCE DRAWING, FIREFIGHTING EQUIPMENT LAYOUT DRAWING, CATHODIC PROTECTION DRAWING, SKETCH, SHOP DRAWING, PIPING LAYOUT DRAWING, STRUCTURAL DRAWING, EQUIPMENT LAYOUT DRAWING, SUPPORT DRAWING, OUTLINE DRAWING, FOUNDATION LAYOUT DRAWING, PILE MAKE-UP DETAILS, INSTALLATION DETAIL, API PLAN, DETAIL DRAWING, REINFORCEMENT DRAWING, UPS BATTERY ROOM LAYOUT DRAWING, HAZARDOUS AREA CLASSIFICATION DRAWING, CABLE TRAY LAYOUT DRAWING, INSULATION AND HEAT TRACING DRAWING, TYPICAL DESIGN DRAWING, TRENCH LAYOUT DRAWING, FOOTPRINT DRAWING, PASSIVE FIRE PROTECTION DRAWING, PROCESS HOOK-UP DRAWING
description: A <DRAWING> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> which has the purpose of <PROVIDING> a graphic representation of shape or layout
An <API PLAN> is a <PLAN> and a <DRAWING> that indicates cooling water hook-up and supply to various equipment components
a document which has the purpose of providing a graphic representation of shape or layout
A <CRANKSHAFT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> representing a crankshaft
A <INSTALLATION DETAIL> is a <DRAWING> that contains information to assist with installation of an item
A <PIPE SUPPORT DETAIL> is a <DRAWING> that shows details of either a typical support installation or an installation for an engineered support
A <PNEUMATIC HOOK-UP DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that is showing pneumatic connections including the location of the connections, connections types, sizes etc
A <PROCESS HOOK-UP DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that is showing connections to the process system including the location of the connections, connections types, sizes etc
An <INSULATION DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that is detailing insulation, including anchoring and expansion joints, etc. Includes refractory
A <CABLE TRAY LAYOUT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that shows the layout of cable trays for electrical and instrumentation cables
An <EMERGENCY EQUIPMENT AND EXITS DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that gives details about escape routes, means of emergency escape and the location of all lifesaving equipment
An <EQUIPMENT CROSS SECTION DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that shows cross sectional views of an <EQUIPMENT ITEM>
An <EQUIPMENT INSTALLATION DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that gives detailed step by step pictorial instructions for the assembly of an <EQUIPMENT ITEM>

An <EQUIPMENT LOCATION DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that shows the physical location of all equipment, and the exact position of detectors/alarms and for detectors as well as their orientation and fire area covered
A <UPS BATTERY ROOM LAYOUT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that details the layout of a <UPS BATTERY ROOM>
A <FIREFIGHTING EQUIPMENT LAYOUT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that details the location of all portable/semi portable fire fighting equipment
A <FOUNDATION DESIGN DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that details of foundation design for construction
A <FOUNDATION LAYOUT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that shows an arrangement in plan view depicting the location of foundation/pile supports

A <FOUNDATION LOADING DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that details static and dynamic forces or movements acting on foundations or other load bearing supports, anchor bolt details,lengths and pre-tensioning. May include Civil Structural for loads imposed, and Civil Foundations for foundation design
A <HAZARDOUS AREA CLASSIFICATION DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that provides information on the level of explosion proofing etc. required in each area
An <INSULATION AND HEAT TRACING DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that details about heat tracing and insulation; It may include anchoring and expansion joint details where applicable
A <PASSIVE FIRE PROTECTION DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that is a structural and module drawing detailing the passive fire protection i.e. firewall/boundary fire protection ratings
A <PILE MAKE-UP DETAILS> is a <DRAWING> that shows the make up of <PILE>
A <PIPING LAYOUT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that shows the precise location of piping and ducting within a facility, relative to surrounding structures and equipment
A <REINFORCEMENT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that gives details about steel reinforcement in concrete structures
A <ROUTING DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that shows alignment of cables and pipelines between facilities
A <SAFETY ZONE DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that shows the main safety features (e.g. containment) of the facility. Typically related to toxic zones. e.g. H2S Zone Diagram
A <SUBSTRUCTURE STEEL DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that details the steel construction of a <SUBSTRUCTURE>
A <STRUCTURAL DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that gives details about the construction of a <BUILDING> or other <STRUCTURE>
A <SUPPORT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that, in general, details the <SUPPORT> of plant items; per type of plant item specializations of this dcoument type are prepared
A <TENDON DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that details the anchoring of deep water structures using <TENDON>s
A <TRENCH LAYOUT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that details the layout of <TRENCH>es for <ROUTING> <ELECTRICAL CABLE>s and/or <SIGNAL CABLE>s through a facility
An <UNDERGROUND SERVICE LAYOUT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that shows all underground objects and is made for interdiscpilinary coordination purposes
A <CATHODIC PROTECTION DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that is showing locations of cathodic protection
A <SKETCH> is a <DRAWING> that describes an object briefly by drawing the outline or prominent features of same
An <EQUIPMENT LAYOUT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> showing the location of major equipment in a 2D or 3D coordinate system
An <INTERFACE DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> containing data about physical object connections including the location of the connections, connections types, dimensions etc
A <TYPICAL DESIGN DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> showing a standard assembly or design that is reused at multiple locations across a plant or insatallation

A <PIPING ISOMETRIC DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that is a schematic center-line representation of a pipng system, presenting it in three dimensions; In order for a design to appear three dimensional, a 30 degree angle is applied to its sides, thus creating an isometric projection. It includes basic information about pipes, valves, fittings, welds etc. and how they are interconnected and located using a 2D or 3D coordinate system,
A <SHOP DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> showing additional information prepared for manufacturing purposes
A <LOGIC AND SEQUENCE DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> showing information related to instrument and electrical software functions, but not the graphical representation

A <FOUNDATION DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> including the following following information; the outer dimensions and footprint of the support frame or foundaton supports, the size, grade and location of the foundation bolts and torque where this is necessary, force and moments transfered to load bearing structures (normal/extreme conditions), details for adjustment and alignment

A <FOOTPRINT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> including as a minimum the footprint of the support frame or foundaton supports, the size, grade and location of the foundation bolts and torque where this is necessary, force and moments transfered to load bearing structures (normal/extreme conditions), details for adjustment and alignment
A <GENERAL ARRANGEMENT DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> showing the location of artefacts in a 2D or 3D coordinate system
An <ASSEMBLY DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> showing how a type of assembled items are assembled from parts
A <DETAIL DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> showing details of a type of artefact
An <OUTLINE DRAWING> is a <DRAWING> that is indicating/representing the shape of a type of products

subclasses: emergency response procedure
description: An <EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> detailing how the facility would respond to an emergency and how personnel would be able to evacuate
a procedure detailing how the facility would respond to an emergency and how personnel would be able to evacuate. As defined for Facilities Operations and for Pipeline Operations
An <ENQUIRY> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> about equipment, materials and service requirements. It includes the contractual conditions that will apply to the eventual purchase order

subclasses: forming, heat treatment procedure
description: A <FORMING AND HEAT TREATMENT PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> detailing heating, soak, cooling parameters, limits of strain during forming, temperature ranges, method of attachment of thermocouples, temperature control, equipment calibration, production testing, etc

superclasses: general procedure, FORMING AND HEAT TREATMENT PROCEDURE
description: a procedure detailing heating, soak, cooling parameters, limits of strain during forming, temperature ranges, method of attachment of thermocouples, temperature control, equipment calibration, production testing, etc

subclasses: handling, shipping, storage procedure
description: A <HANDLING, SHIPPING AND STORAGE PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> that defines details of the manner that goods shall be handled, shipped and stored

superclasses: general procedure, HANDLING, SHIPPING AND STORAGE PROCEDURE
description: a procedure indicate size of container, number off, weight, identification and contents, include detail preservation procedure detailing inspection periods, materials required etc., both prior to installation and post installation, but prior to commissioning. Any special unpacking/handling requirements shall be stated

subclasses: MANPOWER HISTOGRAM, general histogram
description: A <HISTOGRAM> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> with the purpose of <REPRESENTING> a ditribution of numerical data
a document with the purpose of representing a ditribution of numerical data
A <MANPOWER HISTOGRAM> is an <InformationObject> and a <HISTOGRAM> that shows current and predicted manpower through project broken down by trade/profession
An <INSPECTION PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> that contains instructions on how to inspect an item
An <INSTALLATION PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> that describes how to install an item

An <INTERFACE DOCUMENT> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> that includes the information in the <INTERFACE REGISTER>, the <INTERFACE DIAGRAM>, and the <TIE-IN LIST>. This document establishes a comprehensive coherent and transparent overview for all interfaces between two execution contract. This document is included within the corresponding ITTs

subclasses: interface procedure
description: A <INTERFACE PROCEDURE> is an <InformationObject> and a <PROCEDURE> and a <DOCUMENT> that describes Interface management activities between internal and external parties (esp. between contract scopes)
a procedures around Interface management activities between internal and external parties

A <JOB DESCRIPTION> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> that is a broad, general, and written statement of a specific job, based on the findings of a job analysis. It generally includes duties, purpose, responsibilities, scope, and working conditions of a job along with the job&amp;amp;#39;s title, and the name or designation of the person to whom the employee reports

subclasses: MATERIAL REQUISITION LINE ITEM, PURCHASE ORDER LINE ITEM
description: A <LINE ITEM> is an <InformationObject> and a (part of a) <DOCUMENT> that is a unit of information in a document, record, or statement, shown on a separate, numbered, line of its own
An <MATERIAL REQUISITION LINE ITEM> is a <LINE ITEM> that is a part of a <MATERIAL REQUISITION>
A <PURCHASE ORDER LINE ITEM> is a <LINE ITEM> that is a part of a <PURCHASE ORDER>

subclasses: CERTIFICATE LIST, BOLT LIST, REGISTER, PACKING LIST, PROGRAM, BILL OF MATERIALS, PARTS LIST, DOCUMENT CATALOGUE, SHIP PARTICULARS, BILL OF QUANTITIES, SUPPORT LIST, ALARM AND TRIP SETTING LIST, SPARE PART LIST, PUNCH LIST, CONSOLIDATED SPARE PARTS LIST, SUPPLIERS LIST, ELECTRICAL LOAD LIST, TIE-IN LIST, MANUAL VALVE LIST, INDEX, REFERENCE LIST, SCHEDULE(list), DISTRIBUTION BOARD LIST, ACTION LIST, AGENDA, SUBCONTRACTED WORK LIST, MAILING LIST, CERTIFIED EQUIPMENT LIST, APPLICABLE STANDARDS LIST, INPUT-OUTPUT LIST, general list, EQUIPMENT SUMMARY LIST, EQUIPMENT LIST
description: A <LIST> is an <InformationObject> and a <DOCUMENT> with the purpose of <PRESENTING> a number if items in a sequence
a collection of values with a relationship to a specific topic or object that could be either technical or business related
An <INDEX> is a <LIST> to capture some facts about relevant objects for look up
An <AGENDA> is a <LIST> of subjects to be haNdled or discussed during a meeting
A <CERTIFICATE LIST> is a <LIST> that includes certificates
A <PARTS LIST> is a <LIST> containing all components or parts that the described artefact or item consists of
A <SHIP PARTICULARS> is a <LIST> that includes ship basic information, specific details, characteristics and properties, typically related to main dimensions, draught, displacement, stability, etc

An <ELECTRICAL LOAD LIST> is a <LIST> that is the electrical load schedule, that is an estimate of the instantaneous electrical loads operating in a facility, in terms of active, reactive and apparent power (measured in kW, kVAR> and kVA respectively). The load schedule is usually categorised by switchboard or occasionally by sub-facility / area
A <CONSOLIDATED SPARE PARTS LIST> is a <LIST> of spare parts that is generated to support execution of project purchasing for the purpose of commissioning, start-up, maintenance support, etc
An <ACTION LIST> is a <LIST> of activities for tracking responsible parties and status, including but not limited to punch lists, issues lists, and check lists
A <MANUAL VALVE LIST> is a <LIST> of manually operated <VALVE>s
An <ALARM AND TRIP SETTING LIST> is a <LIST> that shows each instrument having an alarm or trip function

An <APPLICABLE STANDARDS LIST> is a <LIST> of Company Standards identified for use as baseline standards for a project. It also provides: - The list of International, National and Industry Codes &amp; Standards that are referenced in the Company Standards and project specific Specifications. - The list of Codes (e.g. process unit codes) to be used by the project
A <BILL OF MATERIALS> is a <LIST> of all parts and sub assemblies that constitute a particular assembly, showing the quantity of each required item
A <BILL OF QUANTITIES> is a <LIST> of whole assemblies or bulk material showing the quantity of each required to suit a purpose. Compare Bill of Materials for sub assemblies and parts

A <BOLT LIST> is a <LIST> that indicates number, type, size and material of all fixing bolts required. Where temporary bolts are required to withstand transportation forces these shall also be indicated with suitable note of explanation
A <CERTIFIED EQUIPMENT LIST> is a <LIST> that provides an overview of all <CERTIFIED EQUIPMENT>
A <DISTRIBUTION BOARD LIST> is a <LIST> the lighting and small power loads connected to a distribution board
An <EQUIPMENT SUMMARY LIST> is a <LIST> that is an extract from an <EQUIPMENT LIST> that is used for secondary reference purposes

An <INPUT-OUTPUT LIST> is a <LIST> that shows input and output of an equipment (e.g. instrument, telecom equipment, electrical equipment) connected to other equipments (e.g. distributed control system, programmable logic controller). Typically includes: Tag Number/s, Instrument Class, Service description, I/O type, Process function, etc

A <PACKING LIST> is a <LIST> of articles usually included in each shipping package, giving the quantity, description, and weight of the contents. Prepared by the shipper and sent to the consignee for accurate tallying of the delivered goods

A <SPARE PART LIST> is a <LIST> of interchangeable parts that are kept in an inventory and used for the repair or replacement of failed units; Capital spares are spare parts which, although acknowledged to have a long life or a small chance of failure, would cause a long shutdown of equipment because it would take a long time to get a replacement for them
A <SUBCONTRACTED WORK LIST> is a <LIST> of work to be subcontracted, including subcontractor, scope and value
A <SUPPORT LIST> is a <LIST> that includes pipe, cable, instrument, foundation and other supports
A <TIE-IN LIST> is a <LIST> that includes interfaces between project stages, contractors and systems (eg. new to existing plant connections)
A <REGISTER> is a <LIST> that is an official record of names or items

A <PUNCH LIST> is a <LIST> that is prepared near the end of a construction project listing work not conforming to contract specifications that the general contractor must complete prior to final payment

A <DOCUMENT CATALOGUE> is a <LIST>, linking documents to equipment, facilities, work packs, work orders, procedures and tasks, manufacturer and supplier information, as appropriate for particular document types. Includes definition of document types
